title: Brexit flexible extension agreed by EU as date officially changes to January 31
text:

The October 31 Brexit date is officially dead today after EU leaders finally agreed a delay to leaving the EU.

Donald Tusk said the 27 leaders have agreed the UK's request for a "flextension" until 31 January 2020.

It is thought that means Britain will have the option of leaving the EU earlier - at the end of November or December - if MPs and the European Parliament pass a withdrawal agreement before then.

It comes despite Boris Johnson repeatedly promising he would not ask for a delay to Brexit - claiming he would rather "die in a ditch" than fail to leave on Halloween.

A decision was originally due last Friday but was held up as France disagreed over the terms of an extension. In the end EU leaders struck a compromise where an extension will last three months, but might be cut short if a deal is agreed after all.

(Image: REUTERS)

European Council President Donald Tusk announced the decision this morning after a meeting of EU ambassadors lasting barely half an hour.

He tweeted: "The EU27 has agreed that it will accept the UK's request for a Brexit flextension until 31 January 2020.

"The decision is expected to be formalised through a written procedure."

Boris Johnson was forced to request the three-month delay by MPs - who also rejected his attempt to rush through a Brexit deal in just three days. But even a delay it wasn't his choice, asking for it still broke the PM's pledge.

The flailing Tory Prime Minister had said last month: "There are no circumstances in which I will ask Brussels to delay. We are leaving on 31 October, no ifs or buts."

It comes as MPs hold a showdown vote from 5pm tonight over whether to hold a Christmas snap election.

Labour are expected to vote down Boris Johnson's bid to hold a snap election on December 12 - because they say it'd leave open a no-deal Brexit .

But just as that motion dies, a separate bid is gaining momentum from the SNP and Lib Dems which pushes for a December 9 election instead.

Crucially, because it's a Bill this second bid would only need half of all voting MPs to back it - not the 434-MP 'super majority' that Boris Johnson needs tonight.

A vote could be held on the fresh election bid as soon as tomorrow, and pass even if it doesn't have Labour backing. No10 said it would consider backing “something like” this option if it loses tonight’s vote.

Furious Labour blasted the Lib Dem and SNP bid as a "ridiculous stunt" as Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell raged: "Looks like the Lib Dem and Tory pact of 2010 is being re-established.

"They are back together, selling out the People’s Vote campaign and the cross party campaign to prevent a no deal.

"The Lib Dems will stop at nothing to get their ministerial cars back."

But despite Labour's fury and initial Tory brush-offs the fresh election bid appeared to be gathering momentum.

Yesterday, Tory chairman James Cleverly branded the Lib Dem plan a “gimmick” while Culture Secretary Nicky Morgan also called it a “stunt”.

Yet last night government aide Bim Afolami said: "I'm not necessarily averse to it." And today schools minister Nick Gibb did not rule out backing a move similar to the Lib Dems', despite accusing the party of "disobeying" the 2016 vote to leave the EU.

A source also told Reuters the election bid was a factor that persuaded EU leaders to get a three-month extension over the line.

Labour has insisted it won't back an election until no-deal Brexit is taken off the table.

That had been widely thought to mean a no-deal on October 31.

But Jeremy Corbyn has since suggested it also includes a threat of a no-deal in 2021 - one which is wrapped up in Boris Johnson's Brexit deal.

There was a slim chance Labour - which has told MPs to abstain or vote against an election tonight - could change its tune before tonight's vote.

Jeremy Corbyn was due to summon a meeting of his shadow cabinet later today.

This breaking news story is being updated.
description: The October 31 leaving date is officially dead despite Boris Johnson's vow to 'die in a ditch' after the announcement by European Council chief Donald Tusk
